prior_works.title: Submodular functions and convexity
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provided the Lovász extension and showed SFM is equivalent to minimizing a convex function over the hypercube, giving the continuous viewpoint (and Lipschitz properties in ℓ∞) that the paper exploits to design low-depth parallel algorithms.

prior_works.title: A combinatorial algorithm minimizing submodular functions in strongly polynomial time
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Established a landmark combinatorial, strongly polynomial algorithm for SFM, serving as a core sequential baseline the paper contrasts with when seeking depth–query trade-offs beyond sequential paradigms.

prior_works.title: A Combinatorial, Strongly Polynomial-Time Algorithm for Minimizing Submodular Functions
prior_works.authors: Satoru Iwata, Lisa Fleischer, Satoru Fujishige
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Introduced the IFF framework for strongly polynomial SFM, underpinning the classic algorithmic toolkit from which prior (non-parallel) methods derive and which motivates the search for fundamentally parallel approaches.

prior_works.title: A Faster Strongly Polynomial Algorithm for Submodular Function Minimization
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Advanced the best-known sequential complexity for exact SFM, highlighting that prior progress largely optimized sequential time—precisely the axis this paper departs from by prioritizing low parallel depth.

prior_works.title: A Faster Cutting Plane Method and its Implications for Combinatorial and Convex Optimization
prior_works.authors: Yin Tat Lee, Aaron Sidford, Sam Chiu-wai Wong
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Showed how modern cutting-plane/convex optimization tools yield faster SFM, directly informing the paper’s continuous perspective and its query–depth trade-offs that leverage convex structure over the hypercube.

prior_works.title: Problem Complexity and Method Efficiency in Optimization
prior_works.authors: A. S. Nemirovski, D. B. Yudin
prior_works.role: Black-box convex optimization and mirror/subgradient methods
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Established oracle-complexity foundations and norm-specific first-order schemes (e.g., ℓ1/ℓ∞ geometry) that the paper leverages to craft the first highly-parallel algorithm for minimizing ℓ∞-Lipschitz convex functions on the hypercube.

prior_works.title: Random Gradient-Free Minimization of Convex Functions
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Developed zeroth-order methods well-suited to parallelization for ℓ2-Lipschitz convex minimization; prior parallel SFM approaches passed through this ℓ2 route, which the paper surpasses by addressing the ℓ∞-Lipschitz case directly.

synthesis_narrative:
The core innovation in Parallel Submodular Function Minimization is to obtain new query-versus-depth trade-offs for exact SFM, including a depth-2 algorithm with n^{O(M)} queries and a poly-query algorithm with depth ~ n^{1/3} M^{2/3}, by exploiting the convex structure of the Lovász extension in a geometry tailored to ℓ∞. Lovász’s seminal reduction of SFM to convex minimization over the hypercube is the conceptual linchpin, as it both justifies a continuous approach and reveals bounded-range submodular functions as ℓ∞-Lipschitz. Classic sequential milestones—Schrijver, Iwata–Fleischer–Fujishige, and Orlin—form the dominant algorithmic lineage the paper moves beyond: rather than optimizing sequential time, it targets minimal adaptivity (depth) under oracle access.
A second influential strand is the use of convex-analytic tools for SFM, epitomized by the cutting-plane breakthroughs of Lee–Sidford–Wong, which underscored the power of continuous relaxations. On the convex optimization side, the oracle-complexity framework of Nemirovski–Yudin (and mirror/subgradient methods in ℓ1/ℓ∞ geometry) provides both algorithmic scaffolding and near-optimality yardsticks for black-box Lipschitz minimization. Prior highly-parallel reductions to SFM predominantly flowed through ℓ2-Lipschitz convex minimization (e.g., Nesterov–Spokoiny’s gradient-free schemes), which are naturally parallelizable but misaligned with the ℓ∞ Lipschitzness inherent to Lovász extensions. By designing the first highly-parallel minimization algorithm tailored to ℓ∞-Lipschitz objectives on the hypercube, the paper closes this geometric gap and, together with the convex reduction, yields its improved depth–query trade-offs for SFM.
